resources.string: Used for auto-update system to install new versions from GitHub releases. Only used when user explicitly enables auto-updates and app was not installed from Google Play Store.
Required for Bluetooth and WiFi conditional filtering features. Used to detect nearby Bluetooth devices and WiFi networks for user-defined rules. No location tracking or data collection.
Required for Bluetooth conditional filtering. Allows the app to detect when specific Bluetooth devices are connected for notification rules. No data is collected or transmitted.
Required for WiFi network conditional filtering on Android 13+. Allows the app to detect WiFi network changes for user-defined notification rules. No network data is collected.
Used for importing/exporting app settings and configuration files. Allows users to backup and restore their settings. No personal data is accessed.
SpeakThat! needs access to your notifications to read them aloud. This permission is required for the app to function.
💡 Turn off when not needed to save battery
Turn off when not needed to save battery

Choose how SpeakThat handles multiple notifications:
Interrupt - Stops current notification and reads new one immediately. Best for urgent notifications.
Queue - Finishes current notification, then reads new ones in order. Nothing gets missed.
⏭Skip - Ignores new notifications while reading. Simple but you might miss important ones.
Smart (Recommended) - Priority apps interrupt, others queue. Perfect balance of urgency and completeness.
Smart mode lets you choose which apps are urgent enough to interrupt (like calls, messages) while other apps wait their turn.
Customize how app names are spoken in notifications
Example: X app reads as Twitter

Choose how SpeakThat handles notifications while music/videos play:
Ignore - Speaks over your media. Simple but can be disruptive.
Pause - Pauses media completely while speaking. Good for podcasts, but interrupts music flow.
Lower Audio - Temporarily reduces media volume so you can hear both.
Silence - Doesn\'t speak while media plays. Quiet but you might miss important notifications.
Lower Audio works like a car radio - it ducks the music down when speaking, then brings it back up.

Shake to Stop lets you instantly silence SpeakThat by shaking your device:
Why it\'s helpful: • Stop embarrassing notifications in quiet places • Quick control when your hands are busy • Works even when screen is off • No fumbling for buttons
How it works: • Shake your device firmly (like a dice shake) • Current notification stops immediately • Queued notifications are cleared • New notifications work normally
Customization: • Adjust sensitivity for your preference • Test your shake strength with the meter • Works great for both gentle and vigorous shakers
This feature is especially loved by people who get notifications during meetings, movies, or while driving.
Skip notifications that are persistent (ongoing) or silent (no sound/vibration)
Persistent notifications are ongoing (like music controls, navigation, etc.) and silent notifications have no sound/vibration. This option helps reduce notification spam from background services.
Ongoing notifications that don\'t auto-dismiss (music controls, navigation)
Notifications with no sound or vibration
Notifications with minimum or low priority level
Notifications from system apps (Android, Google services)

Wave to Stop lets you instantly silence SpeakThat by waving your hand in front of the device:
Why it\'s helpful: • Perfect for users who can\'t shake their device • Great for phones on desks or mounts • Works with one hand • No physical device movement needed • Accessibility-friendly alternative to shake
🎯 How it works: • Wave your hand in front of the device (like a magic gesture) • Uses the proximity sensor to detect hand movement • Current notification stops immediately • Queued notifications are cleared • New notifications work normally
⚙️ Customization: • Adjust sensitivity for your preference • Test your wave detection with the meter • Works great for different hand sizes and distances
This feature is especially useful for accessibility, desk users, and anyone who prefers gesture control over physical movement.
This version of SpeakThat! receives updates through your app store (F-Droid, Google Play Store, etc.).
• Updates are automatically handled by your app store\n• You\'ll receive notifications when updates are available\n• No manual download or installation required
If you want automatic updates directly from GitHub, you can download the GitHub version instead. This version is identical but includes auto-update functionality.
New version ready (%1$s). Tap to open the updater.
Tap to download and install the latest version.
Alerts for new SpeakThat versions in the GitHub build.

SpeakThat! is an open-source Android Notification Reader that announces your notifications aloud using text-to-speech. Perfect for hands-free operation, accessibility, and staying informed while multitasking.

• Real-time notification reading
• Customizable voice settings
• Smart notification filtering
• App-specific controls
• Media-aware behaviour
• Notification history
• Shake/Wave to stop
• Custom speech formatting
• Dark/Light theme support
• Conditional rules for advanced logic and schedules
• Fully ad-free and offline functionality

Developed with ❤️ by Mitchi, a solo developer from the UK with over 12 years of experience testing and using notification readers every day.

SpeakThat! was inspired by Touchless Notifications, originally developed by DYNA Logix, and aims to carry forth the legacy of customisable notification readers.

This project was accelerated by AI-assisted programming.

SpeakThat is free and open-source software, released under the GNU GPL v3.0, a copyleft license that ensures modified and redistributed versions remain free and properly attributed.

This license allows you to download, modify, and redistribute SpeakThat, provided that any redistributed or modified versions remain under the same license and retain the original copyright notices.

You can view the full license text and source code on GitHub. Contributions and feedback are welcome!

SpeakThat! Copyright © Mitchell Bell
SPEAKTHAT is a registered trademark of Mitchell Bell

SpeakThat is an open-source Android Notification Reader that announces your notifications aloud using text-to-speech. Perfect for hands-free operation, accessibility, and staying informed while multitasking.

Real-time notification reading, customizable voice settings, smart notification filtering, app-specific controls, media-aware behaviour, notification history tracking, Shake to Stop and Wave to Stop, custom speech formatting, dark mode and light mode support, conditional rules for advanced logic and schedules, and fully ad-free, offline functionality.

Developed with love by Mitchi, a solo developer from the UK with over 12 years of experience testing and using notification readers every day. SpeakThat was inspired by Touchless Notifications, originally developed by DYNA Logix, and aims to carry forth the legacy of customisable notification readers. This project was accelerated by Artificial Intelligence assisted programming.

SpeakThat is free and open-source software, released under the GNU GPL v3.0, a copyleft license that ensures modified and redistributed versions remain free and properly attributed. This license allows you to download, modify, and redistribute SpeakThat, provided that any redistributed or modified versions remain under the same license and retain the original copyright notices. You can view the full license text and source code on GitHub. Contributions and feedback are welcome! SpeakThat is the copyright-protected work of Mitchell Bell. SPEAKTHAT is a registered trademark of Mitchell Bell

SpeakThat is an open-source Android Notification Reader that announces your notifications aloud using text-to-speech. Perfect for hands-free operation, accessibility, and staying informed while multitasking.

Real-time notification reading, customizable voice settings, smart notification filtering, app-specific controls, media-aware behaviour, notification history tracking, Shake to Stop and Wave to Stop, custom speech formatting, dark mode and light mode support, conditional rules for advanced logic and schedules, and full ad-free, offline functionality.

Developed with love by Mitchi, a solo developer from the UK with over 12 years of experience testing and using notification readers every day. SpeakThat was inspired by Touchless Notifications, originally developed by DYNA Logix, and aims to carry forth the legacy of customisable notification readers. This project was accelerated by Artificial Intelligence assisted programming.

SpeakThat is free and open-source software, released under the GNU GPL v3.0, a copyleft license that ensures modified and redistributed versions remain free and properly attributed. This is how your notifications will sound with these voice settings.
SpeakThat needs to restart to apply the new TTS engine. Restart now?
By the way, SpeakThat was unable to use your selected text-to-speech engine. Please open Voice Settings to choose another engine.
SpeakThat couldn\'t use your selected TTS engine. It may have been uninstalled. The system default engine is now being used.
Choose your preferred language and theme to get started with SpeakThat.
Welcome to SpeakThat! Stay connected without staring at your screen. Your phone will read notifications aloud so you can focus on what matters.
SpeakThat needs permission to read your notifications aloud. Everything stays on your device and you control what gets read.
Your privacy matters. You control exactly what gets read aloud. Shake your phone to stop any announcement instantly. Everything stays on your device.
Let\'s set up some basic privacy filters to get you started. SpeakThat features a powerful filtering system that allows you to choose what gets read and what doesn\'t.
Type the name of an app you want me to never read notifications from. Common examples include banking apps, medical apps, and dating apps.
Type words or phrases that you want me to never read notifications containing. Common examples include password, PIN, credit card, and medical terms.

Set up smart rules that automatically control when notifications are read based on your situation. For example, only read notifications when headphones are connected, or skip notifications when the screen is on.
SpeakThat is ready to help you stay connected while keeping your eyes free! You can add more filters anytime in the app settings.
Select a pre-configured rule template to get started quickly, or create a custom rule from scratch.
Select your Bluetooth headphones, and notifications will ONLY be read when they are connected to your phone
Select two times you want SpeakThat to remain silent between
Notifications will only be read if your screen is off
Enter your Home WiFi network and notifications will only be read when you\'re connected to it
When not connected to Home WiFi

Some Android versions have security restrictions that prevent apps from detecting specific WiFi network names. While SpeakThat can currently detect your WiFi network, this functionality may not work reliably in all situations (especially when the app is in the background).

The rule will fall back to detecting WiFi connection state if SSID detection fails, but it may not work exactly as expected.

It's not impossible to implement properly, however. So if you're a better developer than me then please contribute on the GitHub.

These settings are for users who need granular control over the voice and accent.

99% of users should only change the main Language option.

If you run into trouble, you can always reset to defaults.

Set how quiet media should become during notifications
⚠️ On some devices, lowering media volume may also lower the notification voice. If notifications are still hard to hear, try Pause mode or adjust your TTS settings.
Tip: Lower values make media quieter during notifications
⚠️ Lower Audio works differently across devices and Android versions. Some devices may not duck certain apps or audio streams properly.

If ducking isn\'t working well: Try different audio streams in Voice Settings (\'Voice Call\' or \'Notification\' often work best). Avoid \'Media\' stream as it may duck your TTS along with your music.
The app automatically uses advanced system ducking when available, with smooth manual ducking as backup for maximum compatibility.

Lower Audio works differently across devices. Some devices may not respond to volume changes properly, which could affect your TTS volume.\n\nYou can still enable this feature, but be aware it may not work consistently on all devices.

Remember dismissed notifications to prevent re-reading them
Enable if notifications get read again after dismissal

Benefits:

• Prevents re-reading dismissed notifications
• Stops notifications from being read after you dismiss them
• Configurable memory duration (5 min to 1 hour)
• Automatic cleanup to save memory and battery
How long to remember dismissed notifications

Dismissal Memory prevents notifications from being read again after you dismiss them:

What it does:
When you dismiss a notification, SpeakThat remembers it for a configurable period. If the same notification content appears again during this time, it will not be read aloud.

When it is useful:
• Dismissed notifications - Prevents re-reading after you swipe them away
• App updates - Some apps re-post notifications after updates
• System refreshes - Android may re-post notifications during system events
• Network reconnections - Apps may re-post notifications when connectivity is restored

How it works:
• Tracks dismissed notifications by content hash
• Configurable memory duration (5 min to 1 hour)
• Automatic cleanup to prevent memory bloat
• Battery-friendly with efficient storage
• Detailed logging for troubleshooting

Tip: Enable this if you experience notifications being read again after dismissal. Most users will benefit from this feature!
Choose how SpeakThat behaves in Silent and Vibrate. Keep both quiet, or let Vibrate keep talking while Silent stays muted.
Recommended: Keep both Silent and Vibrate honoured

Benefits:

• Prevents unwanted audio in Silent
• Optional speech while on Vibrate
• Matches your meeting/focus needs
• Works with physical volume buttons

SpeakThat! uses the AccessibilityService API to provide optional control features such as pausing speech using hardware buttons and smoother integration with media apps.
This permission allows the app to detect button presses and user interface actions, giving you more ways to control readouts. No personal or sensitive user data is collected, stored, or shared — all processing happens entirely on your device.
This permission is completely optional; SpeakThat! will still function without it.
Enables advanced control features for SpeakThat including volume button shortcuts to stop/pause notification reading. This service is completely optional and all processing stays on your device.
Stop notification reading by pressing both volume buttons simultaneously. Normal volume control still works. Requires accessibility permission.

Press both volume buttons simultaneously to stop notification reading.
Perfect for hands-free control:
• Works from anywhere in the system
• No need to look at the screen
• Quick and reliable
• Normal volume control still works
⚠️ Requires Accessibility Permission:
This feature needs the accessibility permission to detect volume button presses. You can enable it in General Settings.
Please note that this will only work when the screen is on.
Press to Stop requires the accessibility permission to detect volume button presses. Please enable it in General Settings first.

Hey! Mitchi here. A lot goes into making SpeakThat! I handle the UI/UX design, quality assurance and testing, project management, distribution and publishing, app store compliance, and user support just to name a few!

If SpeakThat has been helpful for you, or if you would have paid for it, please consider supporting its development!

Every donation keeps this app totally free and open-source for everyone who needs it.

Thank you! ❤️
Tools for debugging and testing the app
This screen shows notifications that SpeakThat! has captured for debugging purposes. It helps you verify that the app is working correctly and see exactly what notifications are being read aloud.
Create powerful rules to control when SpeakThat reads notifications based on your device state, time, and connections.
No automation, SpeakThat! remains permanently active.
Use the internal automation in SpeakThat! for Bluetooth device detection, time schedules, etc.
Enable intents for third-party automation tools such as MacroDroid or Tasker.

SpeakThat can only use one automation source at a time.

Off - Keep automation disabled so SpeakThat remains active until you toggle the master switch manually.

Conditional Rules - Use the built-in automation logic for Bluetooth devices, schedules, and filters. (Recommended)

External Automation - Enable broadcast intents for automation tools (e.g., MacroDroid, Tasker) to control SpeakThat directly.
Select Conditional Rules to create automations, or leave this mode selected to keep SpeakThat always active.
SpeakThat is waiting for automation intents. Switch back to Conditional Rules to edit internal automations.
Tap a row to copy the value.
Enable the flag \"INCLUDE_STOPPED_PACKAGES\\" so intents still reach SpeakThat! after reboot, and use the flag \"RECEIVER_FOREGROUND\" if your automation app supports it for faster delivery.

Optional: an \"Extra\" slot can be used to identify the automation in debug logs. Set the parameter name to \"source\", and the value to a key identifier of your choosing (e.g. \"enable-speakthat-when-i-get-home\") so you can tell which profile toggled the master switch.
SpeakThat enabled - notifications will be read
SpeakThat disabled - notifications will be silent

🔐 Everything stays on your device
SpeakThat features a powerful filtering system that allows YOU to choose what gets read and what doesn\'t.\n\nLet\'s set up some basic privacy filters to get you started.

Type words or phrases that you want me to NEVER read notifications containing!\n\nCommon examples: password, PIN, credit card, medical terms

Set up smart rules that automatically control when notifications are read based on your situation.\n\nFor example, only read notifications when headphones are connected, or skip notifications when the screen is on.
SpeakThat is ready to help you stay connected while keeping your eyes free!\n\n💡 You can add more filters anytime in the app settings.

Calibrate your device to detect hand waves and silence notifications

• Move your hand closer and farther from the sensor for 8 seconds
• We'll record sensor readings every 50ms
• Need at least 20 readings for calibration
• Set threshold to 60% of maximum distance detected
Select Bluetooth devices that must be connected for notifications to be read.

• Notifications will only be read when at least one selected device is connected

• If no devices are selected, all notifications will be read

• The device must be paired and connected (not just discovered)
Enter the exact name of your WiFi network (SSID). The name must match exactly, including case sensitivity.
💡 Tip: You can find your WiFi name in your phone\'s WiFi settings

Settings to improve accessibility and ease of use
Set how long to listen for gestures before automatically stopping (to save battery)
Stop readouts instantly by waving your hand in front of the device

Content Cap lets you limit how much of each notification gets read aloud:

Word Count - Read only the first N words
• Perfect for payment notifications where important info is at the start
• Works reliably across most languages
• Note: Counts words in both title and body combined
• Example: Payment of $50.00 from John Smith for lunch → Payment of $50.00 from John

Sentence Count - Read only the first N complete sentences
• More natural breaks than word limits
• Uses smart sentence detection for international languages
• Handles line breaks in emails properly
• Note: Titles without sentence-ending punctuation don't count as separate sentences
• Example: Hello! How are you today? → Hello!

Time Limit - Stop reading after N seconds
• Universal - works with all languages
• Predictable notification durations
• Great for consistent timing
• Example: Stops after 10 seconds regardless of content length

Tips:
• Word count works best for most users
• Sentence count is more natural but may be less precise
• Time limit is universal and predictable
• All options work with your existing speech templates

• Combine with Shake to Stop for maximum control
Audio ducking works differently across devices and Android versions. Some devices may not duck certain apps or audio streams properly.

If ducking isn\'t working well: Try different audio streams in Voice Settings (\'Voice Call\' or \'Notification\' often work best). Avoid \'Media\' stream as it may duck your TTS along with your music.
The app automatically uses advanced system ducking when available, with smooth manual ducking as backup for maximum compatibility.
ヒント: 値を下げると通知中のメディア音量が小さくなります
Set the percentage of your sensor\'s maximum distance that will trigger wave-to-stop. (Only works on certain devices)
Test your wave detection. Binary sensors show 0 (close) or max (far).
Different phones work differently - some only see \'near\' or \'far\', others see everything in between.\n \nIt\'s normal if this bar only goes to the extremes!
Exception when condition is NOT met
Apply the rule when the condition is NOT met
Set the time range when this rule should be applied:
SpeakThat only supports one voice at a time. If you receive notifications in multiple languages, some may sound garbled.

SpeakThat currently only supports one voice at a time. This means:

✅ What works well:
• Notifications in the same language as your selected voice
• Single-language usage scenarios
• Most common notification patterns

⚠️ Potential issues:
• Notifications in different languages may sound garbled
• Mixed-language content might be difficult to understand
• Some characters or accents may not be pronounced correctly

💡 Recommendations:
• Choose a voice that matches your most common notification language
• Consider using the Language & Region setting instead of Specific Voice
• Test with your actual notifications to ensure clarity

🔮 Future plans:
• Multi-language voice support is planned for future updates
• Automatic language detection and voice switching
• Better handling of mixed-language content

For now, the Language & Region setting often works better for multi-language users as it automatically adapts to different content types.
Search apps or enter package name

Disable fallback methods for media behaviour. If a feature doesn\'t work, it won\'t try alternatives. Helps isolate issues. Note: When disabled, duck mode will fall back to pause mode if ducking fails. If both fail, notifications will still be read without audio focus.

Force the experimental ducking methods (direct media-session pauses and manual STREAM_MUSIC volume changes). Helps stubborn apps like PowerAmp, but can fight ringer settings or leave apps muted if SpeakThat crashes.

SpeakThat is working correctly. Notifications are being received and read aloud.
The test notification could not be posted. This is likely a permission issue. Please ensure the POST_NOTIFICATIONS permission is granted.
The notification appeared on your screen, but the NotificationListener service did not receive it. Try toggling the notification permission off and on in system settings.
The SpeakThat master switch is disabled. Please enable it in the main screen to allow notifications to be read.
Your device is in Silent or Vibrate mode, and you have \"Honor Audio Mode\" enabled. Notifications will not be read in this mode. You can disable \"Honor Audio Mode\" in Voice Settings.
Do Not Disturb mode is active, and you have \"Honor Do Not Disturb\" enabled. Notifications will not be read in this mode. You can disable \"Honor Do Not Disturb\" in Voice Settings.
The notification was blocked by your rules system. Check your rules configuration to ensure they\'re not blocking all notifications.
The notification was blocked by content filtering. Check your app filters, word filters, or other filtering settings.
Text-to-Speech is not initialized. Try restarting the app or checking your TTS engine settings.
The notification was received but not read for an unknown reason. Please export the debug logs and report this issue.
TTS completed successfully, but you didn\'t hear it. Check your volume settings, audio output device (Bluetooth headphones, etc.), or try a different audio stream in Voice Settings.
